newsitem.title: FRANCE: New BoF members not anti-European - Trichet.
newsitem.headline: New BoF members not anti-European - Trichet.

text.p: Bank of France head Jean-Claude Trichet praised the two new members of the central bank's monetary policy council as distinguished personalities and said neither was against European monetary union.
In an interview with French TF1 television late on Thursday, he also said that future euro single currency must be as solid as the franc.

The nomination earlier this month of Pierre Guillen and Jean-Rene Bernard to the nine-member council prompted some speculation about a softening in the Bank of France's defence of the franc-mark exchange rate, seen as the cornerstone of the future European single currency.
Newspapers suggested Guillen in particular might be opposed to the drive to monetary union, an accusation he himself has denied.
Trichet said the legal procedure for naming the two members had been "scrupulously respected".

"These two people are distinguished people who have each had top responsabilities in their field and...contrary to what has sometimes been said, they are not anti-European and they did not vote 'no' to Maastricht (in a 1992 French referendum on the Maastricht treaty," he added.

He declined to say what the Bank's own recommendation had been for the posts, though French newspapers have said he had sought the reappointment of ex-journalist Jean Boissonnat, a staunch supporter of Trichet.
Asked whether the Bank of France still had room to cut official short-term interest rates, he said that it had already reduced these significantly in the last year-and-a-half.

"This was rigourously in line with an increase in confidence in our own currency and I would say also to a large extent, which is a good thing, in confidence in European monetary union. The three elements go together."
As regards the euro, Trichet said that he did not believe French people wanted to change their own currency for one which was less solid.
"Therefore you obviously have to show...that the future currency will be as solid as the one we have now," he said.
